awd_titl_txt: A Multiscale Approach to Characterizing Interfacial Carbohydrate-Active Enzymes
awd_abstract_narration:
The project investigates the molecular underpinnings of how enzymes break down insoluble cellulosic biomaterials to soluble fermentable sugars like glucose and how to make them more efficient to enable industrial-scale biofuel production.  The results of the study will aid the development of lower-cost bioprocesses for producing renewable fuels from cellulosic biomass while providing a broad range of educational and outreach activities promoting training and general awareness of the potential that biofuels offer toward a sustainable and renewable energy future.

The study will examine the relationship between non-productive stalling and binding interactions of cellulases with varying surface chemistry to crystalline cellulose surfaces with the goal of engineering more active enzyme variants.  Specific aims toward achieving this goal involve: 1) design and production of cellulase variants with non-native surface chemistry using both cell-based and cell-free protein expression systems, 2) estimates of the binding affinity of cellulase variants to crystalline cellulose and its relationship to ensemble-averaged bulk cellulase specific activity, and 3) determine the interfacially bound single-molecule surface motility for cellulase variants and correlating single-molecule events to bulk ensemble binding and specific activity measurements.  High throughput cell-free protein expression and combinatorial cellulose hydrolytic activity assays will be carried out to identify improved cellulase variants.  Single-molecule cellulase binding and motility measurements will be conducted using an optical tweezers force spectroscopy technique.  Together with ensemble-averaged bulk measurements, the study will provide new insight into both the protein surface residues and discrete single-enzyme biomechanical steps involved in the non-productive interfacial binding and catalytic activity of crystalline cellulose surface bound cellulases, thereby charting a genetic engineering path that enables a lower cost and more efficient bioconversion process for making cellulosic biofuels.  The researchers will engage students at all levels as well as high school teachers in age-appropriate activities ranging from in-depth training in cellulase engineering and single-molecule biophysics for graduate and undergraduate students to demonstration programs for younger students and generating biofuels awareness through field-trips to local energy industries.

This project is co-funded by the Division of Materials Research through the BioMaPs funds.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to unravel the molecular underpinnings of how cellulolytic enzymes break down cellulosic biomass (e.g., corn stover) into fermentable sugars and develop engineered enzymes for more efficient bioconversion of biomass to sugars for enabling cost-effective biofuels production. Our central hypothesis is that non-productive binding of cellulases to crystalline cellulose surfaces reduces catalytic activity, driven by heterogeneous hydrophobic enzyme-substrate interactions, that can be rationally engineered by selectively altering cellulase surface chemistry. Additionally, we examined the relationship between non-productive binding interactions of cellulases to crystalline cellulose surfaces using cutting-edge single molecule force spectroscopy type techniques with the goal of unraveling the enzyme reaction mechanisms to ultimately engineer more active cellulase variants.

We were successfully able to engineer several types of industrially relevant cellulase enzymes using a computational protein supercharging design approach that enabled up to 5-10x faster conversion activity on insoluble cellulosic biomass to soluble sugars for the very first time. We were also able to leverage this approach to create a large library of mutant enzymes belonging to native cellulolytic microbes with cellulose degradation capabilities relevant to industrial biotechnology. This work led to the discovery of a several novel mutant enzyme designs that were more efficient than native cellulolytic enzymes and resulted in a US patent application. We expect to submit additional patent applications on novel mutants still under characterization in this project. Future work will look to develop this protein engineering approach to create a synergistic cocktail of engineered enzymes for more efficient conversion of lignocellulose to sugars for cost-effective biofuels production.

Additionally, we also developed and applied a cutting-edge bioanalytical technique, called single-molecule force spectroscopy, for detailed characterization of cellulolytic enzymes to unravel its reaction mechanism and identify the key rate-limiting steps impacting cellulase activity on distinct cellulosic substrates. This work led to unravelling the reaction mechanism of key industry workhorse cellulolytic enzymes (e.g., processive cellulases) with single-molecule enzyme motion resolution during cellulose deconstruction into soluble sugars. This helped us detect for the first time the processive motion of cellulases bound to the cellulose surface with sub-nanometer scale resolution and discover previously unknown reaction mechanisms employed by cellulolytic enzymes for cellulose degradation. Ultimately, this work provided mechanistic insights that supported development of novel enzyme biocatalysts and will ultimately lead to improved bioconversion processes for sustainable conversion of lignocellulosic biomass to biofuels. Future work will look to apply such novel techniques for further characterization of mutant cellulolytic enzymes to unravel the complex mechanochemical mechanisms employed during biopolymer catalysis at solid-liquid interfaces.

This project also provided a unique opportunity for multidisciplinary training of several graduate (MS and PhD) and undergraduate students, including several students from under-represented groups, in various aspects of hands-on training on diverse areas relevant to enzyme design/engineering, single-molecule microscopy, protein biophysics, biocatalysis, and cellulosic biofuels. This training also enabled student led multiple publications in several high impact journals over the project duration. Two graduate students also received additional hands-on training at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory and had the opportunity to closely engage with a commercial company involved in developing hardware/software for enabling cutting-edge single-molecule microscopy experiments relevant to biocatalysis and life science applications. In addition, support from this award led to the development of outreach educational materials focused on demonstrating to students how to use cellulase enzymes for converting biomass to biofuels.  Training and outreach activities enabled by this award has also led to several students to pursue an industrial career in biotechnology, while some others pursued their doctoral studies in Engineering & Life Sciences at several other leading research universities around the US.


Last Modified: 08/11/2023
Modified by: Shishir Chundawat
